description.en:
The course involves a study of human rights issues drawing mainly on material from European and international human rights law and domestic legal systems of Europe and North-America. It highlights the key controversies in modern human rights law, and the possible range of responses in different jurisdictions. 

The course begins with an introduction to comparative human rights. We will then consider the similarities and differences between the basic human rights texts of the jurisdictions and the basic theoretical and legal approaches to protection of human rights. 

We will then proceed with considering the meaning of particular human rights and their significance in theory and in practice, and the efficacy of the legal institutions designed to protect them. Several specific substantive issues (minority rights, freedom of speech, privacy and equality) will be studied in depth to illustrate the complex interplay between theory, legal concepts and procedure, and between legal and non-legal sources of protection. The course as a whole will aim to provide the opportunity for in-depth comparative study, during which the appropriateness, utility and limits of the comparative legal techniques will be considered.The focus is on comparing reasoning in actual court cases and analyzing them in the larger human rights framework.The topics of the course may change every year.
description.et: Õppeaine pakub võimalust mõista ja analüüsida inimõigusi erinevates jurisdiktsioonides võrdlevalt. Õppeaine raames keskendutakse peamiselt Euroopa ja rahvusvahelise õiguse inimõigusalasele praktikale ning siseriiklikule kohtupraktikale Euroopas ja Põhja-Ameerikas. Teemakäsitlus algab teoreetiliste lähtekohtade analüüsiga ning võrdleva meetodi tutvustamisega ning jätkub üksikute inimõiguste (nt vähemuste õigused, sõnavabadus, eraelu kaitse ning soolise ja usulise diskrimineerimise keeld) põhjalikuma käsitlusega, et mõista teooria, õiguslike mõistete ja praktika omavahelisi seoseid ning hinnata inimõiguste kaitse vahendite effektiivsust ning võrdleva meetodi kasulikkust ja piiratust õigusmõistmisel. Konreetsed teemad võivad olenevalt aktuaalsusest aastate lõikes varieeruda.

notes.et: For successful participation in this course it is recommended to have basic knowledge of international and regional human rights law and system of protection. The course is best suited for students who have previously attended the course on public international law or other courses that included a section on international or constitutional human rights protection. In this regard the course is best suited for foreign/visiting and University of Tartu 3rd year BA, MA and doctoral students. The course is open for non-lawyers. When in doubt about your abilities to take this course discuss it with your teacher.

independent_work.et:
There are two components to the individual work:  preparation for the seminar and research papers.

1. You are expected to read materials given for each seminar. You should work through the material in a way to be able to give a short summary of the reading material in the class and express your opinion about what you have read. You will not be able to follow the seminar discussion if you have not read the relevant material. This material can be demanding, and you should allocate sufficient time to read it carefully. You should be using the seminar to test ideas about the reading you have done for that week.

2. You have to write a research (conference) paper during the course, which is mandatory for the successful completition of the course. The paper should be related to the course content.   The paper should be no less than 2000 words long (including footnotes) and no more than 2500 words (including footnotes). The paper should be submitted a week before the seminar where you present your paper. The papers are assessed during the dedicated seminars for the presentations and discussion where you get feedback from your teacher and fellow students. For that purpose you will prepare a short presentation of the main ideas expressed in the paper and be prepared to answer questions about your paper. You will also need to act as a moderator of a session and be a discussant for at least two research papers.

description.et: The research paper should be written on the topic covered in the seminars. The essay should be analytical (non-descriptive). It should address the research question in a thorough, logical and coherent manner. The paper should be based on relevant and sufficient sources and materials to provide reasoned and convincing opinions on the matter under discussion. The research paper must follow the style and citation guide adopted in the law faculty or OSCOLA. It is important for the student to be able to defend/discuss his or her essay in the short presentation at the seminar dedicated to essay discussion, respond to questions and criticism. The assessment of fellow students' essays should be thorough, constructive and follow the instructions provided by your teacher in moodle.The discussion seminars will be held in the style of a conference where students participate as active moderators, discussants, presenters and panel members.

grade_preconditions.et: Active participation in all seminars, completed paper assignment and assessment of papers of your fellow students according to guidelines provided by your teacher in moodle. Your research paper should be submitted a week before the seminar dedicated to your paper discussion to enable your teacher and fellow students to give you thorough feedback  at the paper discussion seminars. The discussion seminars will be held in the style of a real conference where sudents have to be moderators, discussants, key speakers, and panel members.

grade_evaluation.et:
1) A student has to actively participate in seminars, be able to give a short summary of the reading material, express opinions about the reading, and be able to point out problematic aspects of the topics covered in the reading. Additionally, active seminar participation includes  reading, providing constructive criticism and contributing to the discussion of all papers written by fellow students. Research papers  are forwarded to students a week before assessment along with instructions on what to pay attention to when assessing/criticizing the papers. Each student has to thouroughly assess (be a discussant) of at least two papers both in writing (max 500 words in moodle, including 3 questions to the prenenter sent before the respective seminar).  and at the seminar.

2) The research paper (conference paper) 

The final grade is made up from 2 segments: research paper- 50% and oral class presentation combined with activism (incl paper discussion, moderating, speaking) in the class (50 %).
